title: At close of business on 17 March 2021, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 27 January 2021?
preds:
Only one forecast out of 17 members expect a hike in 2022, which means range will remain the same in 2021.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/15/why-this-weeks-fed-meeting-could-be-march-madness-for-markets.html

The Fed chairman has indicated that the rate will remain same even if the inflation moves up.
Hence there are high chances that there will be no change.
https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/fomc-meeting-federal-reserve/
Even though I don't know much about the Federal Reserve, with only 7 days until the deadline, it's doubtful that their target range for Federal Funds will change that much.

1. FMOC median forecasts indicate that the rates will remain the same till 2022.
2. Any change will be considered by the committee upon health recovery and economic recovery
3. Economic recovery is dependent upon employment levels and inflation.
(https://www.economicsonline.co.uk/business_economics/federal-interest-rate-projections-for-2021.html).
Hence, in my opinion, the upper limit will almost remain the same.

Not exactly sure, because I don't know much about U.S. federal fund rates. I think they would already be pretty low, so I do not think there is a chance that they would be even lower by March. January to March is a small gap to make anything higher, but there could be a small chance. I think they the rate would stay the same.

The Feds very rarely change their targets, especially amidst an economic recovery. The government also has a vested political interest in keeping rates low to bolster economic growth [1]. Even so, the rates are already ultra-low, meaning that it is likely unfeasible to lower them any further. As a result, I suspect it is virtually impossible for the Federal Reserve to raise or lower rates. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-05/ultra-low-interest-rates-here-to-stay-2021-central-bank-guide
I don't understand any of the stuff in here
Project to remain the same for a while. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FEDTARMD

The target rate for January 27th was 0-0.25%.  The target rate has remained at this level since April 1, 2020 and is expected to remain at this level for the next month at least.  https://apps.newyorkfed.org/markets/autorates/fed%20funds
there is a consensus of other forecasters since a lot of weeks

The target rates have been 0.00-0.25 percent since April 1, 2020.  Given this steady rate over the course of the pandemic, this trend is expected to continue. Additionally, the Federal Open Market Committee made future projections on December 16, 2020.  These projections list the same federal funds rate not just for 2021, but for years into the future. https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomcprojtabl20201216.htm
Latest Fed meeting, per WSJ, reinforces plans to keep interest rates "near zero" for at least three years.

With no sign of inflation and signs of economic slowdown due to escalating virus cases, there is no reason to believe a higher rate will be the target.  While there is discussion of the fed considering negative rates, the lack of this action in American history along with the potential implications leads me to believe this will not be the target in the next month and a half.  The target remaining the same is therefore a near certainty.
No reason to alter that this time.  Will wait until 27 Jan to see what the rate is.

The Fed communicated its intent to leave the target rate at its current level through at least 2021 (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/04/powell-says-duration-of-low-interest-rates-will-be-measured-in-years.html).  Coupled with earlier talk of "flexible average inflation targeting" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/05/fed-holds-interest-rates-steady-near-zero-says-economy-is-still-well-below-pre-pandemic-levels.html), it seems highly unlikely the Fed will adjust rates anytime soon.  And since, they've already rejected negative interest rates I think 0-.25% rates will be around for a while, even if inflation creeps north of 2%.
Unemployment will still be high and the pandemic will still be raging.  I don’t believe the US will go to negative rates in the foreseeable future. Rates will likely be unchanged until 2022.

There is plenty of monetary stimulus already but it may be in the wrong places (see stock market values to find the money). Surge in covid could cause imposition of negative rates on banks to get money out of banks and into circulation.
Fed is not gonna change unless Powell is replaced
As the economy looks to recover the federal government will look to add to the deficit. Keeping rates the same, or raising them slightly seems more likely than a further loosening of the rates.

The FED has signaled that it won't raise interest rates for a while.  Combine that with the uncertainty of the U.S. government formation and the rise in COVID restrictions and they will endeavor to hold steady until employment increases and the Fiscal policy of the U.S. Government is more clear. It can't go any lower and have a postiive effect on the economy. If they do anything they will raise it slightly to compensate for fiscal efforts and the GDP growth in the 3rd and 4th Qtrs.
Stimulus will still be the name of the game
The economy in the US is running on borrowed money, but rates are at historic lows, which would argue for the same or lower rates going into the Spring.

Only two meetings between today and that date, and inflation seems unlikely to pick up significantly until then (see TIPS spreads). The Fed has also signaled that it won't raise rates until inflation is above 2% for a while. The Fed has never (at least not in recent history) lowered the upper limit without lowering the lower limit. But the lower limit is already at zero. Thus, the Fed is likely to increase asset purchases or change forward guidance if it had to respond to deflationary pressures.
all quiet on the western front. I would change my mind if sth. like a massive stimulus package à la Green New Deal came around before end of January (2%) so it could take effect by march (50%).

would take a lot to see inflation spike this quickly with ample spare capacity - process of raising rates will be gradual and steps taken in 1Q21 if any are more likely to be related to QE and other programs vs. changing benchmark rates

Fed Chairs typically hint at rate increases 1 or 2 quarters before implementing changes through the FOMC transcripts. The language coming out of the November FOMC meeting was that we'd have 0 interest rates for at least a few years. https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/fomc-meeting-federal-reserve/. The timespan of this forecast is very short (for the federal reserve) and negative interest rates are not actively being considered by the US Federal Reserve.  This forecast hinges on a massive inflation shock, which is unlikely. In the future, I will update this forecast if government spending increases (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FGEXPND), if inflation exceeds 1-3 percent growth rates (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPIAUCSL#0), and if the language in FOMC minutes suggest a rate increase in imminent.

I see the FED standing pat while they commence QE4 and technical operations like " Operation Twist
not going to  0 or negative
Nothing will change rate policy for foreseeable future, then a tightening.
on looking at other contestants I under bid, very much stronger on it staying the same.

US has never had negative rates, however on the other-hand there is precedent for other markets to do this. After 2008 there was a seven year period where rates were maintained as such so three months is not so much to be expected. There will only be one meeting.
fight against Covid19 still active in March 21

Don't expect any significant change to happen in by March. The pandemic still continues to rage which means that the economy will continue to operate below it's normal capacity. This means that despite the fed pumping money into the economy and the stimulus we still havent seen inflation pick up. There has been a shift of control monetary policy from central banks to governments across the globe which means that we should see inflation pick up as things normalize. Dont see that happening by March as of now

Fed FOMC 2020-11-05: ”The Committee decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to 1/4 percent and expects it will be appropriate to maintain this target range until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee's assessments of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.” Important points:
* inflation has to exceed 2 and remain there for some time
* maximum employment in the near future is an unlikely assessment

The FED has committed to low rates. I don't expect 2% inflation or full employment within the timeframe of the question so this one seems certain. https://nationalmortgageprofessional.com/news/75884/federal-reserve-commits-interest-rates#:~:text=The%20Federal%20Reserve%20Board's%20Federal,0%20to%20one%2Dquarter%20percent.
